content: The "Family Economic Stimulus Act of 2008" includes a retroactive, 2-year moratorium on including unemployment compensation in gross income for taxable years 2007 and 2008. Additionally, there is a temporary increase in the child tax credit. The "Family Economic Stimulus Act of 2008" includes a temporary increase in the child tax credit to $1,200 for the first taxable year beginning in 2008. Additionally, there is a 2008 stimulus credit outlined in section 6428 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Family Economic Stimulus Act of 2008" provides a tax credit of $400 ($800 for joint returns) for eligible individuals in their first taxable year beginning in 2008. The credit is reduced to zero if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds the threshold amount of $115,000 for joint filers and heads of household. An eligible individual excludes estates, trusts, nonresident aliens, and individuals for whom a deduction under section 151 is claimed by another taxpayer. The credit is reduced by refunds and credits received under subsection (e) and is split equally for joint returns. Each eligible individual's first taxable year starting in 2006 is treated as having made a payment against the tax imposed by chapter 1 in an amount equal to the advance refund amount. The advance refund amount is the credit that would have been allowed for that taxable year if certain conditions were met.
